page.title: A Protestant Parliament for a Protestant People

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2013}} '''A Protestant parliament for a Protestant people''' is a term that has been applied to the political institutions in [[Northern Ireland]] between 1921 and 1972. The term has been documented as early as February 1939, when [[Bishop Daniel Mageean]], in his [[Lent]]en [[Pastoral letter|pastoral]], stated that prime minister, [[Lord Craigavon]] had adopted the words as his slogan.
The implication was that [[Irish Catholic]]s had no political status in the country.<ref>[[The Times]],''"Dread of Nocturnal Visits " In Ulster'' 20 February 1939; pg 19; col C</ref> Many of them supported the [[Nationalist Party (Northern Ireland)|Nationalist Party]] that chose a policy of [[Abstentionism#In_Northern_Ireland|abstentionism]] between 1921 and 1965, resulting in a large majority of Protestant members. They also alleged that local [[Gerrymandering#Northern_Ireland|gerrymandering]] had increased since 1921.
The original similar phrase had been published in the 1934 Northern Irish parliamentary debates (volume 16).
==Actual quotation== A bitter debate arose in the [[Parliament of Northern Ireland]] on 24 April 1934 on the rights of the minority (the minority in Northern Ireland being [[Irish Nationalism|Nationalist]] supporters, who were mostly Catholic), itemising how these had generally deteriorated since 1921. Craigavon denied the assertions at length, ending with: "''Since we took up office we have tried to be absolutely fair towards all the citizens of Northern Ireland. Actually, on an [[Orange Order|Orange]] platform, I, myself, laid down the principle, to which I still adhere, that I was Prime Minister not of one section of the community but of all, and that as far as I possibly could I was going to see that fair play was meted out to all classes and creeds without any favour whatever on my part.''"
[[George Leeke]] then retorted: "''What about your Protestant Parliament?''", to which Craigavon replied: "''The hon. Member must remember that in the South they boasted of a Catholic State. They still boast of [[Irish Free State|Southern Ireland]] being a Catholic State. All I boast of is that we are a Protestant Parliament and a Protestant State. It would be rather interesting for historians of the future to compare a Catholic State launched in the South with a Protestant State launched in the North and to see which gets on the better and prospers the more. It is most interesting for me at the moment to watch how they are progressing. I am doing my best always to top the bill and to be ahead of the South.''"<ref>[http://www.ahds.ac.uk/stormontpapers/pageview.html?volumeno=16&pageno=1095 Vol. 16, page 1095 original text online; downloaded February 2010] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303190258/http://www.ahds.ac.uk/stormontpapers/pageview.html?volumeno=16&pageno=1095 |date= 3 March 2016 }}</ref>
==Similar usage== Similar phrases he used were ''That is my whole object in carrying on a Protestant Government for a Protestant people''.<ref>[http://cain.ulst.ac.uk/issues/discrimination/quotes.htm Discrimination - Quotations], [[Conflict Archive on the Internet|CAIN]]</ref> The correct phrase was quoted by [[Jonathan Bardon]],<ref>Jonathan Bardon, ''A History of Ulster'' (Blackstaff, 2005), pp. 538-9.</ref> and Professor Ronan Fanning,<ref>[http://www.independent.ie/opinion/analysis/the-age-of-our-craven-deference-is-finally-over-1965621.html R Fanning, Sunday Independent December 2009]</ref> but the common misquotation has been relayed by eminent historians such as [[Diarmaid Ferriter]], [[Se√°n Cronin]], Patrick Buckland and Mark Tierney, to the extent that ''A Protestant Parliament for a Protestant People'' has now become very widely accepted as the actual quotation.<ref>See: Ferriter D. ''The Transformation of Ireland 1900-2000'' London: Profile Press 2004, p.281; {{ISBN|1-86197-307-1}}. Buckland P., ''The Factory of Grievances: Devolved Government in Northern Ireland 1921-1939'' New York: Barnes & Noble; Dublin: Gill & MacMillan 1979, p.72 {{ISBN|0-06-490752-X}}. Cronin S., ''Irish Nationalism: A History of its Roots and Ideology'' New York: Continuum, 1981; p.177 {{ISBN|0-8264-0062-0}}. Tierney M., ''Modern Ireland 1850-1950'' Dublin; Gill and Macmillan, 1978; p.230. {{ISBN|0-7171-0886-4}}.</ref>
In 1967, the then prime minister, [[Terence O'Neill]] also attributed the phrase itself to his predecessor, but strongly argued that it was no longer representative of the present spirit of [[Ulster Unionism]].<ref>The Times, ''Ulster's Prime Minister replies to his critics''; 28 April 1967; pg 11 col E</ref> Newspapers continued to use the term in the 1970s and 1980s, particularly in relation to the former [[Parliament of Northern Ireland|Stormont Parliament]].<ref>''Paradox of political reform at Stormont (News)''; Hugh Munro; '''The Times''' 8 November 1971; pg 12 col F</ref><ref>''Mr Whitelaw denies that Army's hands are tied in military action against Northern Ireland gunmen (News)''; '''The Times''' 12 October 1972; pg 6 col A</ref><ref>''Sectarianism in Ulster (Letters to the Editor)'' BRIAN W. WALKER,, NORMAN GEAR, '''The Times''' 1 June 1973; pg 15 col E</ref><ref>''Unionists cry foul at Stormont football fixture (News),'' ''The Times'', 4 August 1984; pg 1 col B</ref>
==See also== * [[Gerrymandering#Northern Ireland]]

[[File:Anne Newport, Lady Torrington (nee Pierrepont).jpg|thumb|Anne Newport, Lady Torrington (wife of Thomas Newport, 1st Baron Torrington) by and published by John Smith, after Sir Godfrey Kneller, Bt, mezzotint, 1720 (1709) NPG D11609 ]]
'''Anne Newport, Baroness Torrington''' (? - 1735) was an eighteenth-century aristocrat and social reformer.
She was the daughter of Robert Pierrepont and Anne Murray.
She was the third wife of [[Thomas Newport, 1st Baron Torrington|Thomas Newport, Baron Torrington]], a [[barrister]] and [[Lord of the Treasury]]. They married on 8th July 1709, and made their home at [[Richmond House, Twickenham|Richmond House]] in Twickenham.<ref name=":0" /> Anne would continue to live after her husband died in 1719.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.twickenham-museum.org.uk/detail.php?aid=95&cid=17&ctid=1|title=Twickenham Museum - The Earl of Bradford|website=www.twickenham-museum.org.uk|access-date=2018-11-18}}</ref> She was a cousin of noted woman of letters [[Lady Mary Wortley Montagu]].
On 14 April 1730, along with her friend, [[Frances Byron, Baroness Byron|Frances Byron]],<ref name="Wagner2004"/> she was one of the signatories to the [[Signatories to the Ladies' Petition for the Establishment of the Foundling Hospital|Ladies' Petition for the Establishment of a Foundling Hospital]], which would be presented by [[Thomas Coram]] to [[George II of Great Britain|King George II]] in 1735.<ref name="Wagner2004">{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/53361054|title=Thomas Coram, Gent., 1668-1751|last=Gillian.|first=Wagner,|date=2004|publisher=The Boydell Press|year=|isbn=1843830574|location=Woodbridge, Suffolk|pages=88|oclc=53361054}}</ref> These ladies are now considered pioneers in demonstrating the 'Christian, virtuous and humanitarian aspects of such an endeavour and make it socially acceptable ... [and] one of the most fashionable charities of the day.<ref>Elizabeth Einberg, 'Elegant Revolutionaries', article in Ladies of Quality and Distinction Catalogue, Foundling Hospital, London 2018, pp. 14-15, p.15. https://foundlingmuseum.org.uk/events/ladies-of-quality-distinction/</ref>
The extensive collection of fine art developed by the couple was inherited by Thomas' brother Lord Bradford.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://www.historyofparliamentonline.org/volume/1715-1754/member/newport-hon-thomas-1655-1719|title=NEWPORT, Hon. Thomas (?1655-1719), of Brigstock Park, Northants. {{!}} History of Parliament Online|website=www.historyofparliamentonline.org|access-date=2018-11-18}}</ref> It is now on display at Weston Park in [[Shropshire]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.weston-park.com/business-events/cultural-tours/|title=Cultural Tours {{!}} Weston Park|work=Weston Park|access-date=2018-11-18|language=en-GB}}</ref>

{{distinguish|Benefit corporation}}
'''B Corporation''' certification (also known as '''B Lab''' certification or '''B Corp''' certification) is a private certification issued to [[For-profit corporation|for-profit companies]] by [[B Lab]], a global [[501(c) organization|nonprofit]] organization with offices in the United States, Europe, Canada, Australia, New Zealand and a partnership in Latin America with Sistema B. To be granted and to preserve certification, companies must receive a minimum score on an online assessment for "[[Social impact assessment|social and environmental performance]]", satisfy the requirement that the company integrate [[B Lab]] commitments to [[Stakeholder theory|stakeholders]] into [[By-law|company governing documents]], and pay an annual fee ranging from $500 to $50,000.<ref name="Make It Official">{{cite web |title=B Corporation: Welcome |publisher=[[B Lab]] |url=http://www.bcorporation.net/become-a-b-corp/how-to-become-a-b-corp/make-it-official |accessdate=16 May 2014}}</ref>
As of August 2018, there are over 2,600 certified B Corporations across 150 industries in 60 countries.<ref name="B Corporation: Welcome">{{cite web |title=B Corporation: Welcome |publisher=[[B Lab]] |url=http://www.bcorporation.net/ |accessdate=August, 2018}}</ref>
==Purpose== [[File:Runa B Corp Label.jpg|thumb|Example of a B Corp certification label|193x193px]] The B Lab certification is a third party standard requiring companies to meet [[social sustainability]] and environmental performance standards, meet accountability standards, and to be [[Sustainability reporting|transparent]] to the public according to the score they receive on the assessment. B Lab certification applies to the whole company across all product lines and issue areas. For-profits of all legal [[business entities|business structures]] are eligible for certification.
===Advantages=== * Similar to other [[Companies law|business associations]], certified B Corporations and their employees have access to a number of discounts from outside entities and fellow members.<ref>{{cite web |title=Save Money and Access Services |publisher=[[B Lab]] |url=http://www.bcorporation.net/become-a-b-corp/why-become-a-b-corp/save-money-and-access-services |accessdate=September 11, 2013}}</ref> * Academic contributions of loan forgiveness.<ref>{{cite web |title=Loan Assistance Program ‚Äî Overview |publisher=Columbia Business School |url=http://www8.gsb.columbia.edu/socialenterprise/careers/loanassistance |accessdate=January 8, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Loan Assistance Program ‚Äì Detailed Summary |publisher=New York University Stern School of Business |url=http://web-docs.stern.nyu.edu/admissions/financial-aid-loan-assistance-program-description-and-policies.pdf |accessdate=January 8, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Loan Forgiveness Program |publisher=[[Yale School of Management]] |url=http://som.yale.edu/our-programs/full-time-mba/admissions/financing-your-mba/loan-forgiveness-program |accessdate=January 8, 2014}}</ref>
===Disadvantages=== * B Lab certification has no legal status.{{citation needed|date=November 2016}}
===Distinction from benefit corporation=== {{further|Benefit corporation}} * Benefit corporation is a legal status conferred by state law in the US; B Lab certification is issued by a private organisation and has no legislative framework.<ref name="What Are B Corps">{{cite web|title=What Are B Corps |publisher=[[B Lab]] |url=https://www.bcorporation.net/what-are-b-corps/legislation |accessdate=16 May 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140517152828/https://www.bcorporation.net/what-are-b-corps/legislation |archivedate=17 May 2014 |df= }}</ref> * B Lab certification is not needed to obtain benefit corporation status.<ref name="What Are B Corps"/> * Legislation for the passage of this corporate legal status has been passed in 30 states, including [[Delaware corporation|Delaware]], whereas B Lab certification is privately issued by an organisation run by people principally issued from the business community.<ref>{{cite web |last=Schwartz |first=Ariel |title=Delaware Just Made It A Whole Lot Easier For Socially Responsible Companies To Exist |publisher=[[Fast Company (magazine)|Fast Company & Inc.]] |date=July 23, 2013 |url=http://www.fastcoexist.com/1682654/delaware-just-made-it-a-whole-lot-easier-for-socially-responsible-companies-to-exist |accessdate=September 11, 2013}}</ref>
==Certification process==
===Online assessment=== To obtain a B Corporation certification, a company first completes an online assessment. Companies that earn a minimum score of 80 out of 200 points undergo an assessment review process, essentially a conference call verifying the claims made in their assessment. Companies are required to provide supporting documentation before they are certified.
The assessment covers the company‚Äôs entire operation and measures the positive impact of the company in areas of [[Corporate governance|governance]], [[Employee engagement|workers]], [[Community service#Personal benefits of serving|community]], the [[Environmental impact|environment]], as well as the product or service the company provides.<ref>{{cite book |author=Network for Business Innovation and Sustainability |title=B Corporations, Benefit Corporations and Social Purpose Corporations: Launching a New Era of Impact-Driven Companies |publisher=NBIS |date=October 2012 |url=http://nbis.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/10/ImpactDrivenCompanies_NBIS_Whitepaper_Oct2012.pdf |page=2}}</ref> [[Social business|Socially]] and environmentally-focused business model points ultimately are accrued in their relevant impact area (governance, workers, community or environment).<ref name=giirs>{{cite web |title=GIIRS Governance |publisher=[[B Lab]] |url=http://giirs.org/about-giirs/how-giirs-works/185 |accessdate=September 11, 2013}}</ref> Depending on a company's industry, geographic location, and number of employees, the online assessment adjusts the weightings of the question categories to increase its relevancy. For instance, companies with more employees will have a heavier weighting in the workers category, and companies in [[Manufacturing sector|manufacturing]] will have a heavier weighting in the environment category.
To maintain credibility, the B Corporation certification standard operates under principles that are independent, comprehensive, comparable, dynamic, and transparent.<ref>{{cite web |title=AB 361 Assembly Bill - BILL ANALYSIS |publisher=[[California State Assembly]] |url=http://www.leginfo.ca.gov/pub/11-12/bill/asm/ab_0351-0400/ab_361_cfa_20110624_120507_sen_comm.html |accessdate=January 8, 2014}}</ref> B Lab has an established standards advisory council that can independently make decisions with or without the support of B Lab.<ref name=giirs /> As of May 2014, 28 of 30 members were listed by their business affiliation.<ref>{{cite web |title=Standards Advisory Council |publisher=[[B Lab]] |url=http://www.bcorporation.net/what-are-b-corps/the-non-profit-behind-b-corps/standards-advisory-council |accessdate=September 11, 2013}}</ref> The council recommends improvements to the B Corp assessment on a biennial basis. There is a 30-day public consultation period before releasing a new version of the B Corporation assessment.<ref name="giirs"/>
Currently the B Corp assessment is its fifth version, with the sixth version scheduled to be released in January 2018.<ref>{{cite web |title=Corporate Social Responsibility Comes In Many Flavors, Some Not So Tasty |publisher=NonProfit Times Publishing Group |url=http://www.thenonprofittimes.com/news-articles/corporate-social-responsibility-comes-in-many-flavors-some-not-so-tasty/}}</ref>
===Legal requirements=== Certification also requires companies to integrate their stakeholder commitments into the company governing documents. In the United States, the avenue for corporations making the legal amendment to certify will depend on the state they are [[Incorporation (business)|incorporated]] in. Some states known as "constituency" states will allow for this change in the articles of incorporation, other states, known as "non-constituency states", will not; and many states now have the option of adopting the [[benefit corporation]] legal structure, which also meets B Lab's requirements for B Corp certification.<ref name=howto>{{cite web |title=Corporation Legal Roadmap |publisher=[[B Lab]] |url=https://www.bcorporation.net/become-a-b-corp/how-to-become-a-b-corp/legal-roadmap/corporation-legal-roadmap |accessdate=September 11, 2013}}</ref> Beyond the corporate model, other for-profit business entities make an amendment of the company by-laws or governing documents. These include: * The establishment of clear wording to "consider stakeholder interests" in company [[Articles of Incorporation|articles of incorporation]] or [[By-law|company by-laws]].<ref name=howto /> * Define "[[stakeholder (corporate)|stakeholders]]" as the employees, the community, the environment, suppliers, customers, and shareholders.<ref name=howto /><ref>See Boatright (2006) and Johnstone and Lionais (2004).</ref> * No prioritization of one stakeholder over another.<ref>{{cite web |title= OLR Backgrounder: Social Enterprise and the Benefit Corporation |publisher=State of Connecticut, Office of Legislative Research |url=http://www.cga.ct.gov/2013/rpt/2013-R-0260.htm}}</ref> * Allowing for the company's values to exist under new management, investors, or ownership.<ref name=howto /><ref>See Lencioni (July 2002).</ref>
However, B Lab certification allows the company bylaws to remain secret.
==International adoption== In September 2018, there were over 2,000 certified B Corporations across 130 industries in 50 countries,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/deborahsweeney/2018/09/13/how-b-corporations-change-the-way-entrepreneurs-think-about-profit-and-consumers/#405f3d5c3470|title=How B Corporations Change The Way Entrepreneurs Think About Profit And Consumers|last=Sweeney|first=Deborah|work=Forbes|access-date=2018-10-11|language=en}}</ref> including [[Canada]] (78 companies), [[Australia]], [[South Africa]], and [[Afghanistan]].<ref name="B Corporation: Welcome"/> The most active community outside of the United States is '''Sistema B'''.<ref>{{cite journal |title= The double bottom line: Profit and social benefit |journal=Business Horizons |url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0007681313001729 | doi=10.1016/j.bushor.2013.10.001 |volume=57 |pages=11‚Äì20}}</ref> Since 2012, Sistema B has been the adaptation of the B Corps movement in [[Latin America]], including in [[Argentina]], [[Brazil]], [[Chile]], [[Uruguay]] and [[Colombia]].<ref>{{cite web |last=Camacho |first=Manuel Antonio |title=In Just a Few Months, Sistema B (AKA: B Corp) Finds Fertile Ground for Social Enterprises in Latin America |url=http://www.nextbillion.net/blogpost.aspx?blogid=2908 |date=August 15, 2012 |publisher=NextBillion.net |accessdate=September 11, 2013}}</ref> This non-profit adapts proprietary certifications and evaluation metrics and modifies both to the context of each country. B Lab also assists Sistema B in incorporating a [[benefit corporation]] distinction into local legal systems.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.socialenterprisebuzz.com/2012/09/26/b-lab-and-sistema-b-partner-to-take-b-corps-global/|title=B Lab and Sistema B Partner to take B Corps Global|last=Ip|first=Melissa|date=September 26, 2012|website=|publisher=Social Enterprise Buzz|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170628141813/http://www.socialenterprisebuzz.com/2012/09/26/b-lab-and-sistema-b-partner-to-take-b-corps-global/|archive-date=28 June 2017|dead-url=|accessdate=September 11, 2013}}</ref>

|journal=Lewis and Clark Law Review |volume=15 |year=2011 |page=1047}} * {{cite journal |last1=Johnstone |first1=Harvey |last2=Lionais |first2=Doug |title=Depleted communities and community business entrepreneurship: revaluing space through place |journal=Entrepreneurship & Regional Development |volume=16 |issue=3 |year=2004 |pages=217‚Äì233 |doi=10.1080/0898562042000197117}} *{{cite journal|last=Lacovara|first=Christopher|title=Strange Creatures: A Hybrid Approach to Fiduciary Duty in Benefit Corporations|journal=Columbia Business Law Review|year=2011|pages=815‚Äì880}} * * {{cite journal|last=Lencioni |first=Patrick M. |authorlink=Patrick Lencioni |title=Make Your Values Mean Something |magazine=[[Harvard Business Review]] |date=July 2002 |url=http://www.brynmawr.edu/businessworkshops/management/documents/Lencioni-Makeyourvaluesmeansomething.pdf |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140309021800/http://www.brynmawr.edu/businessworkshops/management/documents/Lencioni-Makeyourvaluesmeansomething.pdf |archivedate=2014-03-09 |df= }} * {{cite journal|last=Reiser |first=Dana Brakman |title=Benefit Corporations‚ÄîA Sustainable Form of Organization? |journal=[[Wake Forest Law Review]] |volume=46 |year=2011 |page=591 |url=http://wakeforestlawreview.com/benefit-corporations%E2%80%94a-sustainable-form-of-organization |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140424113441/http://wakeforestlawreview.com/benefit-corporations%E2%80%94a-sustainable-form-of-organization |archivedate=2014-04-24 |df= }}

Browder - World Economic Forum Annual Meeting 2011 (cropped).jpg |birth_name = William Felix Browder |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1964|4|23}} |birth_place = [[Chicago]], [[Illinois]], U.S. |death_date = |death_place = |education = [[University of Colorado Boulder|University of Colorado, Boulder]]
[[University of Chicago]] {{small|([[Bachelor of Science|BSc]])}}
[[Stanford University]] {{small|([[Master of Business Administration|MBA]])}} |occupation = CEO, [[Hermitage Capital Management]] |spouse = |children = [[Joshua Browder|Joshua]] |relatives = [[Felix Browder]] {{small|(Father)}}
[[Earl Browder]] {{small|(Grandfather)}}
[[William Browder (mathematician)|William Browder]] {{small|(Uncle)}}
[[Andrew Browder]] {{small|(Uncle)}} }} '''William Felix Browder''' (born 23 April 1964){{cite news|last1=Nordlinger|first1=Jay|title=A Family in History|url=https://www.nationalreview.com/2018/01/family-history-strange-odyssey-browders/|accessdate=March 10, 2018|work=[[National Review]]|date=January 22, 2018}} is an American-born British financier and economist. He is the [[Chief Executive Officer|CEO]] and co-founder of [[Hermitage Capital Management]], an [[investment fund]] that at one time was the largest foreign portfolio investor in Russia.{{cite news|title=The Weekend Interview: The Man Who Stood Up to Putin|work=[[The Wall Street Journal]]|url=https://www.wsj.com/news/articles/SB10001424052702304885404579552120262256240?mg=reno64-wsj&url=http%3A%2F%2Fonline.wsj.com%2Farticle%2FSB10001424052702304885404579552120262256240.html|date=May 9, 2014|access-date=2017-03-13|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170223214024/https://www.wsj.com/news/articles/SB10001424052702304885404579552120262256240?mg=reno64-wsj&url=http%3A%2F%2Fonline.wsj.com%2Farticle%2FSB10001424052702304885404579552120262256240.html|archive-date=2017-02-23|dead-url=yes|df=}} He gave up his U.S. citizenship in 1998 to avoid paying taxes related to foreign investment. After having business in Russia for ten years, Browder was refused entry to Russia in 2005 as a threat to national security; he has said it was because he exposed corruption. After the death in prison in 2009 of [[Sergei Magnitsky]], a Russian lawyer and auditor who had represented his company and conducted an investigation into massive tax fraud related to it, Browder lobbied for Congress to pass the [[Magnitsky Act]], a law to punish Russian human rights violators, which was signed into law in 2012 by President [[Barack Obama]].{{cite web| url=http://the1a.org/shows/2017-07-25/magnitsky-act-supporter-bill-browder-on-russia-putin-and-american-security| title=Magnitsky Act Supporter Bill Browder On Russia, Putin And American Security| date=July 25, 2017| publisher=1A| access-date=August 12, 2017}}{{cite web| url=http://www.slate.com/articles/news_and_politics/trumpcast/2017/07/why_does_putin_hate_the_magnitsky_act.html| title=Why Exactly Does Putin Hate the Magnitsky Act?| author=Jacob Weisberg| date=July 21, 2017| publisher=Slate| access-date=August 12, 2017}} In 2013, Browder was tried in absentia in Russia for tax fraud, jointly in a posthumous prosecution of Magnitsky. He was convicted and sentenced to nine years in prison. [[Interpol]] rejected Russian requests to arrest Browder, saying the case was political. In 2014, the [[European Parliament]] voted for sanctions against 30 Russians believed complicit in the Magnitsky case; this was the first time it had taken such action. In July 2017, Browder testified to the [[United States Senate Committee on the Judiciary|U.S. Senate Judiciary Committee]] on Russia's alleged interference in the [[United States presidential election, 2016|2016 U.S. presidential election]] through use of persons in Washington, D.C. On October 19, 2017, Canada enacted its own Magnitsky Act, which allows for the freezing of assets and visa bans on officials from Russia and other nations considered to be guilty of human rights violations, and prohibits Canadian firms from dealing with foreign nationals who have grossly violated human rights.{{cite news|title=Canada Passes Version Of Magnitsky Act, Raising Moscow's Ire|url=https://www.rferl.org/a/canada-passes-magnistky-act-russia-sanctions/28804814.html|accessdate=October 23, 2017|work=[[Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty]]|date=October 19, 2017}} Other countries including Estonia, Lithuania, and the United Kingdom, have also enacted their own version of the Magnitsky Act. On October 21, 2017, as part of a criminal conviction for tax evasion,{{cite news|last1=Baker|first1=Stephanie|title=Interpol Blocks Russia Request to Arrest Hermitage's Browder|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-10-26/interpol-blocks-russia-s-warrant-to-arrest-hermitage-s-browder|accessdate=January 6, 2018|work=[[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]]|date=October 26, 2017}} the Russian government attempted to place Browder on [[Interpol]]'s arrest list. After a protest by U.S. Congressional leaders, his visa was restored the following day.{{citeweb|first1=Andrew E.|last1=Kramer|work=[[The New York Times]]|title=U.S. Clears Bill Browder to Enter, Rebuking Russia|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/10/23/world/europe/russia-us-magnitsky-browder.html|date=October 23, 2017|accessdate=October 29, 2017}} Russia's arrest-warrant request was rejected by Interpol on October 26, 2017. While visiting Spain in May 2018, Browder was arrested on 30 May 2018 by Spanish authorities on a new Russian Interpol warrant and transferred to an undisclosed Spanish police station,{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-44301072 |title=Bill Browder arrested in Spain on Russian warrant |date=2018-05-30 |work=BBC News |accessdate=2018-05-30}} yet he was released two hours later, after Interpol confirmed that this was a political case.{{cite news |url=https://politica.elpais.com/politica/2018/05/30/actualidad/1527670051_787708.html |title=Detenido durante dos horas en Espa√±a el financiero Bill Browder, cr√≠tico con Putin |date=2018-05-30 |work=El Pais |accessdate=2018-05-30}} ==Early life and education== William Felix Browder was born in [[Chicago|Chicago, Illinois]], the son of mathematician [[Felix Browder]], and the grandson of [[Earl Browder]]. He attended the [[University of Colorado, Boulder]] before transferring to the [[University of Chicago]], from which he graduated with a degree in [[economics]]. He earned an [[MBA]] from [[Stanford Business School]]{{cite news |title=Hermitage CEO Browder: Don't Invest in Russia Today |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=84MsRuC-1l8|date=November 4, 2009 |accessdate=2009-12-15 }} in 1989 and entered the financial sector.{{cite web| url=https://www.gsb.stanford.edu/insights/bill-browder-warning-against-investment-russia| title=Bill Browder: A Warning Against Investment in Russia| date=October 1, 2009| author=Maria Shao| publisher=Stanford Business| access-date=August 12, 2017}} ==Family background== Browder's paternal grandfather was [[Earl Browder]], who was born in Kansas in 1891. He was a radical and had lived in the Soviet Union for several years from 1927 and married Raisa Berkman, a Jewish Russian woman, while living there. After his return to the United States in 1931, Earl Browder became the leader of the [[Communist Party USA]], and ran for U.S. president in 1936 and 1940.{{cite news |first= Clifford J.|last= Levy|authorlink= |title=An Investment Gets Trapped in Kremlin's Vise |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/07/24/world/europe/24kremlin.html?hp=&pagewanted=all |quote=For Mr. Browder, 44, Russia was more than a place to do business. His grandfather Earl Browder was a communist from Kansas who moved to the Soviet Union in 1927, staying for several years and marrying a Russian. He returned with her to the United States to lead the Communist Party for a time, even running for president. |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=July 24, 2008 |accessdate=2008-07-24 }} After World War II, Browder lost favor with Moscow and was expelled from the U.S. Communist Party. Earl and his wife Raisa had three children, all sons, and all three became mathematicians who headed the mathematics departments of top American universities including Bill Browder's father [[Felix Browder]] who married Eva (Tislowitz). Felix was a mathematics prodigy who had entered MIT at 16, acquired his bachelor's degree in two years, and by the age of 20 received a Ph.D. from Princeton. But during the [[McCarthy era]], he could not find work because he was the son of the onetime head of the Communist Party USA.{{cite web| url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/national/felix-browder-mathematician-shadowed-by-his-fathers-life-as-a-communist-dies-at-89/2016/12/15/4bc626da-c215-11e6-8422-eac61c0ef74d_story.html| title=Felix Browder, mathematician shadowed by his father's life as a Communist, dies at 89| author=Matt Schudel| date=December 15, 2016| publisher=The Washington Post| access-date=August 12, 2017}}{{cite web| url=http://www.newyorker.com/tech/elements/remembering-felix-browder-a-nonlinear-genius-in-a-nonlinear-world| title=Remembering Felix Browder, A Nonlinear Genius in a Nonlinear World| author=Thomas Lin| date=December 20, 2016| publisher=The New Yorker| access-date=August 12, 2017}} After a series of job rejections in the 1950s, he was championed by [[Eleanor Roosevelt]], the former First Lady who was then chairman of the board of [[Brandeis University]]; she overrode the rest of the board who were afraid to hire him, and he gained a position at Brandeis. Felix went on to chair the mathematics department at the [[University of Chicago]], and in 1999 became the president of the [[American Mathematical Society]]. Felix Browder was renowned in the field of [[nonlinear functional analysis]] ‚Äî a branch of mathematics with wide applications to such fields as [[physics]], [[engineering]], and [[finance]]. He was instrumental in establishing a science and technology center in conjunction with [[Princeton University]] and [[Bell Labs]]. In 1999, he was awarded the [[National Medal of Science]] by President [[Bill Clinton]], for his "key role in the explosive growth of nonlinear functional analysis and its applications to partial differential equations in recent years". Bill Browder has one sibling, [[Tom Browder]], who entered the University of Chicago at 15, and became a leading [[particle physicist]]. ==Career and citizenship== In 1998, Bill Browder gave up his U.S. citizenship and became a British citizen, partly to avoid paying U.S. taxes on foreign investments.[https://www.cbsnews.com/media/5-citizens-who-left-the-us-to-avoid-paying-tax/3/ Jason McCormick, "5 Citizens Who Left the US to Avoid Paying Tax"], CBS News, 11 July 2012{{cite news |last=Kaminsky|first=Matthew|date=9 May 2014|title=The Man Who Stood Up to Putin|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052702304885404579552120262256240|newspaper=Wall Street Journal|location= |publisher= |accessdate=30 June 2015}} At the time, he was working in the Eastern European practice of the [[Boston Consulting Group]] in London,{{cite web|last=Laroche|first=Julia|date=3 February 2015|title=The man who was once Russia's largest foreign investor says he should've 'never gone there in the first place'|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/bill-browder-profile-2015-2|publisher=Business Insider|accessdate=2 February 2016}} and managed the Russian proprietary investments desk at [[Salomon Brothers]].{{cite web|last=Shao|first=Maria|date=1 October 2009|title=Bill Browder: A Warning Against Investment in Russia|url=https://www.gsb.stanford.edu/insights/bill-browder-warning-against-investment-russia|publisher=GSB.Stanford.EU|accessdate=24 February 2016}} In October 2017, when answering a question about the decision to renounce his U.S. citizenship, he cited "a legacy of bad feeling about the rule of law" as a result of his family having been "viciously persecuted" by U.S. authorities in the 1950s.Matthew Cooper. [http://www.newsweek.com/who-bill-browder-694598 Who is Bill Browder, Vladimir Putin's Enemy Number One?] ''[[Newsweek]]'', 27 October 2017. ===Hermitage Capital Management=== Browder and [[Edmond Safra]] (1932‚Äì1999) founded [[Hermitage Capital Management]] in 1996 for the purpose of investing initial [[Seed money|seed capital]] of $25 million in Russia during the period of the mass [[privatization]] after the [[fall of the Soviet Union]]. [[Beny Steinmetz]] was another of the original investors in Hermitage.{{cite web| url=https://www.foreignaffairs.com/reviews/2015-04-20/putins-hard-turn| title=Putin's Hard Turn| author=Joshua Yaffa| date=May 2015| work=Foreign Affairs| access-date=August 12, 2017}} Following the [[1998 Russian financial crisis|Russian financial crisis of 1998]], Browder remained committed to Hermitage's original mission of investing in Russia, despite significant outflows from the fund. Hermitage became a prominent [[activist shareholder]] in the Russian gas giant [[Gazprom]], the large oil company [[Surgutneftegaz]], [[RAO UES]], [[Sberbank]], [[Sidanco]], [[VSMPO-AVISMA|Avisma]], and Volzhanka."The Hermitage Fund: Media and Corporate Governance in Russia," Harvard Business School Case 703-010, 2002 (26) Browder exposed management corruption and corporate malfeasance in these partly state-owned companies."Gazprom and Hermitage Capital: Shareholder Activism in Russia", Stanford Graduate School of Business Case IB-36, 2002 He has been quoted as saying: "You had to become a shareholder activist if you didn't want everything stolen from you". In 1999, Avisma filed a RICO lawsuit against Browder and other Avisma investors including Kenneth Dart, alleging they illegally siphoned company assets into offshore accounts and then transferred the funds to U.S. accounts at [[Barclays]]. Browder and his co-defendants settled with Avisma in 2000; they sold their Avisma shares as part of the confidential settlement agreement.{{cite web| url=https://100r.org/2014/05/russian-sanctions-highlight-role-of-western-enablers/| title=Russian Sanctions Highlight Role of Western Enablers| date=May 21, 2014| publisher=100 Reporters| access-date=August 12, 2017}} In 1995‚Äì2006 Hermitage Capital Management was one of the largest foreign investors in Russia,{{cite news|title=Magnitsky case: Russia accuses Browder over Gazprom|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-21674303|work=BBC News Europe|accessdate=23 March 2013|quote=In 1995‚Äì2006 Hermitage Capital Management was one of the biggest foreign investors in Russia. Mr. Browder campaigned for the rights of minority shareholders, criticising the governance of Russia's partly state-owned corporations.|date=5 March 2013}} and Browder amassed millions through his management of the fund. In both 2006 and 2007, he earned an estimated ¬£125‚Äì150 million.{{cite news |url=http://business.guardian.co.uk/page/0,,2054487,00.html |title=World's top-earning traders (2006) |accessdate=2008-07-24 |quote= |publisher=Guardian News and Media Limited |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080713012932/http://business.guardian.co.uk/page/0%2C%2C2054487%2C00.html |archivedate=13 July 2008 |deadurl=no |location=London |df= }}{{cite web |url=http://www.thisismoney.co.uk/money/markets/article-1608942/London-boasts-25-of-best-paid-traders.html |title=London boasts 25% of best paid traders |accessdate=2008-07-24 |quote= |publisher=Daily Mail, The Mail on Sunday & Metro Media Group }} In March 2013, [[HSBC]], a bank that serves as the trustee and manager of Hermitage Capital Management, announced that it would end the fund's operations in Russia. The decision was taken amid two legal cases against Browder: a libel court case in London and a trial ''in absentia'' for tax evasion in Moscow.{{cite news|last=Henry Meyer & Jason Corcoran|title=HSBC Shuts Russia's Hermitage as Browder Sued in London|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2013-03-26/hsbc-shutters-hermitage-fund-as-russia-chases-browder-in-courts.html|work=Bloomberg L.P.|accessdate=27 March 2013|date=26 March 2013|quote=HSBC Holdings Plc (HSBA) is closing Hermitage Capital Management Ltd.'s flagship Russia fund just as its co-founder, William Browder, is being sued for libel in London and tried in absentia for tax evasion in Moscow. "It was too small to continue as a viable concern," Browder, 48, said by phone yesterday from London, where he's based. Browder said the closing is "completely" in the hands of HSBC, which is the trustee and manager of the fund.|url-access=subscription}} In June 2018, HSBC reached a settlement with the Russian government to pay a ¬£17 million fine to Russian authorities for its part in alleged tax avoidance.{{Cite news|url=https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/russias-war-on-browder-hits-hsbc-2xjfv6bqw|title=Russia‚Äôs war on Browder hits HSBC|last=Editor|first=Philip Aldrick, Economics|date=2018-06-09|work=The Times|access-date=2018-10-01|language=en|issn=0140-0460}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-06-29/hsbc-in-talks-to-pay-russian-claim-in-browder-linked-case|title=Terms of Service Violation|website=www.bloomberg.com|access-date=2018-10-01}} ===Conflict with Russian government=== In 2005, after ten years of business deals in Russia, Browder was [[blacklist]]ed by the Russian government as a "threat to national security" and denied entry to the country. ''[[The Economist]]'' wrote that the Russian government blacklisted Browder because he interfered with the flow of money to "corrupt bureaucrats and their businessmen accomplices". Other experts on the activities of Western "investors" in Russia in the 1990s were more sympathetic to the Russian government's assessment, citing Browder's earlier settlement agreement with Avisma, which seemed to indicate a long-standing habit of siphoning off funds to offshore accounts. Browder had earlier supported Russian president [[Vladimir Putin]].{{cite news |first= |last= |authorlink= |title=An enemy of the people: The sad fate of a loyal Putinista |url=http://www.economist.com/research/articlesBySubject/displaystory.cfm?subjectid=349002&story_id=E1_VGGTGDT |quote=As the manager of a big Russian investment fund, Bill Browder has contributed to the circulation of the first kind of money‚Äîas well as making a packet for himself, and making his rich clients even richer. But he has also interfered with the supply of the second sort of money‚Äîand been ... |work=[[The Economist]] |date=March 25, 2006 |accessdate=2008-07-24 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080802034442/http://www.economist.com/research/articlesBySubject/displaystory.cfm?subjectid=349002&story_id=E1_VGGTGDT| archivedate= 2 August 2008| deadurl= no}} As reported in 2008 by ''[[The New York Times]]'', "over the next two years several of his associates and lawyers, as well as their relatives, became victims of crimes, including severe beatings and robberies during which documents were taken". In June 2007, dozens of police officers "swooped down on the Moscow offices of Hermitage and its law firm, confiscating documents and computers. When a member of the firm protested that the search was illegal, he was beaten by officers and hospitalized for two weeks, said the firm's head, [[Jamison Firestone|Jamison R. Firestone]]." Hermitage became "victim of what is known in Russia as 'corporate raiding': seizing companies and other assets with the aid of corrupt law enforcement officials and judges". Three Hermitage holding companies were seized on what the company's lawyers insist were bogus charges. The raids in June 2007 allegedly enabled corrupt law enforcement officers to steal the corporate registration documents of three Hermitage holding companies. They allegedly perpetrated a fraud, claiming (and receiving) a rebate of $230 million in taxes paid by those companies to the Russian state in 2006.{{cite news |first=Owen |last=Matthews |authorlink= |title=Where Vultures Prey |url=http://www.newsweek.com/id/218291|quote=Retaliation came quickly. But in fact, he was the Hermitage accountant who handled its tax evasion. Clearly, the conspirators hadn't reckoned on publicity and so decided to cover their backs. They invented a cover story. In January, Sergei Magnitsky, one of Firestone Duncan's top attorneys and auditors, was unexpectedly arrested as he arrived to give evidence to a prosecutor assigned to investigate the case. |work=[[Newsweek]] |date=October 17, 2009 |accessdate=2009-12-15 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20091208055514/http://www.newsweek.com/id/218291| archivedate= 8 December 2009 | deadurl= no}} In November 2008 one of Hermitage's auditors, [[Sergei Magnitsky]], was arrested. He was charged with the very tax evasion that he was investigating.{{cite news |first=Owen |last=Matthews |title=Hermitage and Russia's Vulture Capitalism |url=http://www.newsweek.com/hermitage-and-russias-vulture-capitalism-81441|quote=Retaliation came quickly. Clearly, the conspirators hadn't reckoned on publicity and so decided to cover their backs. In January, Sergei Magnitsky, one of Firestone Duncan's top lawyers, was unexpectedly arrested as he arrived to give evidence to a prosecutor assigned to investigate the case. |work=[[Newsweek]] |date=October 16, 2009 |accessdate=2018-06-29}} Magnitsky died on November 16, 2009 in prison, after eleven months in pretrial detention, nearly the limit allowed under the law.{{cite news |first=William |last=Browder |authorlink= |title=They Killed My Lawyer |url=https://foreignpolicy.com/articles/2009/12/22/they_killed_my_lawyer|quote=Sergei Magnitsky was our attorney, and friend, who died under excruciating circumstances in a Moscow pre-trial detention center on Nov. 16, 2009. |work=[[Foreign Policy]] |date=December 22, 2009 |accessdate=2009-12-26 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20091227060751/http://www.foreignpolicy.com/articles/2009/12/22/they_killed_my_lawyer| archivedate= 27 December 2009 | deadurl= no}} A report linked to by the Wall Street Journal said he died of disease made worse by poor medical treatment.http://online.wsj.com/public/resources/documents/WSJ-20091229-MagnitskyReport.pdf A report by the Physicians for Human Rights in Cambridge, Mass., said the samehttps://s3.amazonaws.com/PHR_Reports/magnitsky-report-july2011.pdf As a result of the controversy related to his arrest and evidence of mistreatment and claimed abuse, his death aroused international coverage and outrage. Magnitsky's death was the catalyst for passage by the U.S. Congress, of the [[Magnitsky Act]], signed into law by President Barack Obama on December 14, 2012. The act directly targeted individuals involved in the Magnitsky affair by prohibiting their entrance to the United States and their use of its banking system. The Russian government retaliated by prohibiting [[adoption]] of Russian children by American citizens, and prohibiting certain individuals from entering Russia. In February 2013, Russian officials announced that Browder and Magnitsky would both be tried for evading $16.8 million in taxes. In March 2013, Russian authorities announced that they would be investigating Hermitage's acquisition of [[Gazprom]] shares worth $70 million. The investigation was to focus on whether Browder violated any Russian laws when Hermitage used Russian companies registered in the region of [[Kalmykia]] to buy shares. An investigation by the Council of Europe's Committee on Legal Affairs and Human Rights cleared Browder of the accusations of improprieties that surfaced at this time.{{cite web|last=Council of Europe's Committee on Legal Affairs and Human Rights|title=Refusing impunity for the killers of Sergei Magnitsky|url=http://www.assembly.coe.int/Communication/ajdoc24_2013.pdf|work=Parliamentary Assembly, Council of Europe|accessdate=10 August 2014|quote=|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140905011145/http://www.assembly.coe.int/Communication/ajdoc24_2013.pdf|archive-date=2014-09-05|dead-url=yes|df=}} At the time, according to the Russian law, foreigners were barred from directly owning Gazprom shares. Browder was also charged with trying to gain access to [[Gazprom]]'s financial reports.{{cite web|title=Police Set to Charge Browder for Buying Gazprom Stock|url=http://www.themoscowtimes.com/news/article/police-set-to-charge-browder-for-buying-gazprom-stock/476533.html|work=The Moscow Time|publisher=Associated Press|accessdate=17 March 2013}} Browder admitted having sought influence in [[Gazprom]], but denied any wrongdoing.[http://www.ft.com/intl/cms/s/0/06df1c16-85b0-11e2-9ee3-00144feabdc0.html#axzz2MmJ9M17B Charles Clover, "Russia alleges $70m fraud against Browder"], ''[[Financial Times]]'', 5 March 2013. He said that purchasing Gazprom shares was an investment in the Russian economy, and the desire to influence the Gazprom management was driven by the need to expose a "huge fraud going on at the company". He also said that the scheme of using Russian-registered subsidiaries entitled to tax advantages was practised by other foreign investors at the time and was not illegal.{{cite news|title=Magnitsky case: Russia accuses Browder over Gazprom|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-21674303|work=BBC News Europe|accessdate=23 March 2013|date=5 March 2013|quote=He said he had bought Gazprom shares in order to invest in the Russian economy and influence the Gazprom management because 'we noticed that there was huge fraud going on at the company'. Mr Browder insists that the way he bought the shares ‚Äì through Russian-registered subsidiaries entitled to tax advantages ‚Äì was legal and used by other foreign investors at the time.}} He also said that he believed the trial was a response to the United States passing the [[Magnitsky Act]], which had blacklisted Russian officials involved in Magnitsky's death, preventing them from entering the U.S. The ''[[Financial Times]]'' reported that this trial was the first in Russian history that included a dead defendant.{{cite news|url=http://www.ft.com/intl/cms/s/0/f7c7d8b4-7919-11e2-b4df-00144feabdc0.html#axzz2LxkkYijU|title=Dead lawyer to go on trial in Russia|last=Clover|first=Charles|author2=Courtney Weaver|date=February 17, 2013|work=The Financial Times|accessdate=26 February 2013}} [[Amnesty International]] described the trial as "a whole new chapter in Russia's worsening human rights record" and a "sinister attempt to deflect attention from those who committed the crimes Magnitsky exposed".{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/russia-set-for-posthumous-magnitsky-trial-8498751.html|title=Russia set for posthumous Magnitsky trial|last=Taylor|first=Jerome|date=February 17, 2013|work=The Independent|publisher=The Independent|accessdate=4 March 2013|location=London}} The American weekly magazine ''[[The Nation]]'' had said in December 2012 that the Magnitsky Act "recklessly and needlessly jeopardized U.S.-Russian cooperation in vital areas from [[Afghanistan]] and the [[Middle East]] to [[international terrorism]] and [[nuclear proliferation]]".[https://www.thenation.com/article/congresss-magnitsky-bill-new-blacklist/ "Is Congress's Magnitsky Bill a New Blacklist?"], ''The Nation'', 14 December 2012 On 11 July 2013, Browder was convicted ''[[trial in absentia|in absentia]]'' by a district criminal court in Moscow on charges under article 199 of the [[Criminal Code of Russia|RF Criminal Code]] ([[tax-evasion]] by organisations), and sentenced to nine years. Magnitsky was posthumously convicted of fraud.[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-23265423 "Russia finds Magnitsky posthumously guilty of fraud"], [[BBC]], 11 July 2013.[http://newsru.com/russia/11jul2013/brauder.html –°—É–¥ –ø—Ä–∏–≥–æ–≤–æ—Ä–∏–ª –ë—Ä–∞—É–¥–µ—Ä–∞ –∫ –¥–µ–≤—è—Ç–∏ –≥–æ–¥–∞–º, –∞ –¥–µ–ª–æ –ø—Ä–∏–∑–Ω–∞–Ω–Ω–æ–≥–æ –≤–∏–Ω–æ–≤–Ω—ã–º –ú–∞–≥–Ω–∏—Ç—Å–∫–æ–≥–æ –ø—Ä–µ–∫—Ä–∞—Ç–∏–ª] [[NEWSru]], 11 July 2013. In May 2013 and again in July 2013, [[Interpol]] rejected requests by Russia's [[Ministry of Internal Affairs (Russia)|Interior Ministry]]{{cite web|url=http://mvd.ru/news/item/1120249/|title=–†–æ—Å—Å–∏—è –æ–±—ä—è–≤–∏–ª–∞ –≤ –º–µ–∂–¥—É–Ω–∞—Ä–æ–¥–Ω—ã–π —Ä–æ–∑—ã—Å–∫ –£–∏–ª—å—è–º–∞ –ë—Ä–∞—É–¥–µ—Ä–∞|website=mvd.ru}} to put Browder on its search list and locate and arrest him, saying that Russia's case against him was "predominantly political".{{cite web|url=http://www.interpol.int/News-and-media/News/2013/N20130726|title=N20130726 / 2013 / News / News and media / Internet / Home ‚Äì INTERPOL|website=www.interpol.int}} In April 2014, the [[European Parliament]] unanimously passed a resolution to impose sanctions on more than 30 Russians complicit in the Magnitsky case; the first time in the parliament's history that a vote was held to establish a public sanctions list.{{cite book | title=Red Notice: How I Became Putin's No. 1 Enemy | publisher=Bantam Press | author=Browder, Bill | authorlink=Bill Browder | year=2015 | isbn=978-0593072950}} However, the vote was only advisory to the European Commission, which did not act on it.{{citation needed|date=June 2018}} In December 2017, Browder was tried in absentia and convicted of tax evasion and deliberate bankruptcy by a Russian court, receiving a sentence of nine years of imprisonment.{{Cite web|url=https://www.rferl.org/a/russia-browder-sentenced-magnitsky-act-/28945792.html|title=Hermitage Capital's Browder Sentenced In Absentia By Moscow Court|website=RadioFreeEurope/RadioLiberty|language=en|access-date=2018-07-14}} On 30 May 2018, Browder was arrested by Spanish police in Madrid on a Russian Interpol arrest warrant. He was freed soon after, when the General Secretary of Interpol warned the Spanish police not to follow the Russian arrest warrant. Browder had come to Spain to brief anti-mafia prosecutor [[Jos√© Grinda]]. After briefing him, Browder returned to the [[United Kingdom]].{{citation needed|date=May 2018}} {{external media| float = right| video1 = [https://www.c-span.org/video/?431852-1/william-browder-overturning-magnitsky-act-putins-top-priority Browder's testimony on the Foreign Agents Registration Act before the Senate Judiciary Committee, July 27, 2017], [[C-SPAN]]}} === 2017 testimony to the U.S. Senate Judiciary Committee === On July 27, 2017, Browder testified to the [[United States Senate Committee on the Judiciary|U.S. Senate Judiciary Committee]] on Russia's alleged interference in the 2016 U.S. presidential election in regards to the [[Foreign Agents Registration Act]] (FARA) and [[Fusion GPS]]. The latter is the [[opposition research]] firm based in [[Washington D.C.]] that commissioned former [[Secret Intelligence Service|MI6]] staffer [[Christopher Steele]] to collect information on [[Donald Trump]]'s ties with Russia. The hearing was set up to examine the firm's separate work on a legal case involving the Magnitsky Act. He directly discussed the President of Russia Vladimir Putin. Browder testified that President Putin is "the biggest oligarch in Russia and the richest man in the world", building a fortune by threatening Russian oligarchs and getting a 50% cut of their profits:
I estimate that he has accumulated $200 billion of ill-gotten gains from these types of operations over his 17 years in power. He keeps his money in the West and all of his money in the West is potentially exposed to asset freezes and confiscation. Therefore, he has a significant and very personal interest in finding a way to get rid of the Magnitsky sanctions.
Browder concluded his statement by reviewing the circumstances that led to U.S. passage of the Magnitsky Act:
I hope that my story will help you understand the methods of Russian operatives in Washington and how they use U.S. enablers to achieve major foreign policy goals without disclosing those interests. I also hope that this story and others like it may lead to a change in the FARA enforcement regime in the future.Rosie Gray: "[https://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2017/07/bill-browders-testimony-to-the-senate-judiciary-committee/534864/ Bill Browder's Testimony to the Senate Judiciary Committee]". ''The Atlantic'', July 25, 2017.[http://www.newsweek.com/forget-jeff-bezos-putin-worlds-richest-man-senate-told-643208 "Forget Jeff Bezos, Putin Is World's Richest Man, Senate Told"], ''Newsweek'', 28 July 2017
=== Book about experiences in Russia === In February 2015, Browder published a book about his career, ''[[Red Notice (book)|Red Notice: A True Story of High Finance, Murder, and One Man's Fight for Justice]]'', focusing on his years spent in Russia and the Russian government's attacks on Hermitage Capital Management. Browder's responses to Russian corruption and his support of the investigation into the death of his attorney [[Sergei Magnitsky]] are at the heart of the book.William Grimes. "[https://www.nytimes.com/2015/02/02/arts/bill-browders-red-notice-about-his-russian-misadventures.html?_r=1 To Russia, With Capitalist Ambitions]". ''The New York Times'', 1 February 2015. A film adaptation written by [[William Nicholson (writer)|William Nicholson]] was reportedly in the works in 2015.{{cite web|url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/hedge-fund-manager-teams-oscar-winning-screenwriter-take-vladimir-putin-1035208|title=Hedge Fund Manager Teams With Oscar-Winning Screenwriter to Take on Vladimir Putin|publisher=}} ===Prevezon civil asset forfeiture case=== In 2013, the U.S. Attorney's Office for New York's Southern District filed a civil asset forfeiture case against Prevezon Holdings Limited, a real estate holding company belonging to Russian businessman [[Denis Katsyv]], based on information from Browder.{{cite web| url=http://www.cnn.com/2017/05/13/world/prevezon-settlement/index.html| title=Russian money-laundering details remain in the dark as US settles fraud case| author=Jose Pagliery| date=May 13, 2017| publisher=CNN| access-date=August 12, 2017}} Prevezon and the Department of Justice settled the case in May 2017 for $5.9 million.{{cite web| url=https://www.justice.gov/usao-sdny/pr/acting-manhattan-us-attorney-announces-59-million-settlement-civil-money-laundering-and| title=Acting Manhattan U.S. Attorney Announces $5.9 Million Settlement Of Civil Money Laundering And Forfeiture Claims Against Real Estate Corporations Alleged To Have Laundered Proceeds Of Russian Tax Fraud| date=May 12, 2017| publisher=United States Department of Justice| access-date=August 12, 2017}} Browder attempted to resist subpoenas that would force him to reveal his sources for information he gave to federal prosecutors. The court ruled that Browder was not required to comply with a subpoena served in Aspen, Colorado, because he "does not live or conduct business transactions regularly in Aspen", but he was required to comply with a subpoena served in New York, where he had been discussing his new book on a television show. He was deposed in April 2015.{{cite web| url=https://blogs.wsj.com/law/2015/03/09/federal-judge-orders-browder-to-comply-with-subpoena-in-money-laundering-case/| title=Federal Judge Orders Browder to Comply with Suboena in Money-Laundering Case| author=Nicle Hong| date=March 9, 2015| publisher=The Wall Street Journal| access-date=August 12, 2017}}{{cite web| url=https://100r.org/media/2017/10/Browder-Deposition-April-15-2015.pdf| title=Videotaped Deposition of William F. Browder| date=April 15, 2015| publisher=United States District Court Southern District of New York| access-date=July 18, 2018}} ===Danske Bank's money laundering case=== In July 2018 Browder warned that [[Danske Bank]]‚Äôs Estonian operations were used to launder as much as $8.3 billion. {{cite web| url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-07-03/danske-may-have-been-used-to-launder-8-3-billion-berlingske| date=July 3, 2018| publisher=Bloomberg| access-date=October 25, 2018}} ==Criticism== [[File:The Global Magnitsky Act Ending Impunity for Human Rights Abusers (17944144821).jpg|thumb|upright=1.5|Browder and others at a 2015 talk hosted by the [[Hudson Institute]]]] A 2016 documentary by [[Andrei Nekrasov]], ''[[The Magnitsky Act ‚Äì Behind the Scenes]]'', "absolves the Russian government of any responsibility for Magnitsky's death"{{cite web|title=How an Anti-Putin Filmmaker Became a Kremlin Stooge|url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/dissident-director-helped-trumps-russia-comrade-attack-us|author=Zavadski, Katie|publisher=''[[The Daily Beast]]''|date=July 25, 2017|access-date=September 26, 2017}} and claims that Browder was behind the $230-million tax-rebate fraud. The film was promoted in Europe and the U.S. by a group that included [[Natalia Veselnitskaya]].{{cite news|title=GOP Lawmaker Got Direction From Moscow, Took It Back to D.C.|url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/gop-lawmaker-got-direction-from-moscow-took-it-back-to-dc|author=Hines, Nico|date=July 19, 2017|publisher=''[[The Daily Beast]]''|access-date=September 26, 2017}} Some European theater screenings and a television broadcast of the film were canceled after threats of libel suits from Browder.{{Cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/06/10/world/europe/sergei-magnitsky-russia-vladimir-putin.html|title=Film About Russian Lawyer's Death Creates an Uproar|last=Landler|first=Mark|date=June 9, 2016|work=[[The New York Times]]|access-date=}} Over Browder's objections, the [[Newseum]] in Washington, D.C. held a screening in June 2016 that was hosted by [[Seymour Hersh]]. [[Dana Rohrabacher]] (R-CA)'s office actively promoted the screening, sending out invitations from the office of the [[United States House Foreign Affairs Subcommittee on Europe, Eurasia and Emerging Threats|House Foreign Affairs Subcommittee on Europe, Eurasia and Emerging Threats]], which Rohrabacher chairs. ===Vladimir Putin statement in Helsinki=== On July 16, 2018, during a joint press conference with President [[Donald Trump]] in [[Helsinki]], [[Finland]], Russian president [[Vladimir Putin]] stated that Browder had funneled $400 million dollars to Hillary Clinton's 2016 presidential campaign, an effort that involved members of the U.S. intelligence community who, Putin said, "accompanied and guided these transactions." The statement was made after Putin said he would allow special counsel [[Robert Mueller]]'s team to come to Russia for their investigation ‚Äì as long as there was a reciprocal arrangement for Russian intelligence to investigate in the U.S. Putin:
For instance, we can bring up Mr. Browder, in this particular case. Business associates of Mr. Browder have earned over $1.5 billion in Russia and never paid any taxes neither in Russia or the United States and yet the money escaped the country. They were transferred to the United States. They sent [a] huge amount of money, $400,000,000, as a contribution to the campaign of Hillary Clinton. (Later, the Russian Prosecutor General‚Äôs Office spokesman Alexander Kurennoy clarified that it was not $400 million, but rather $400,000.{{cite news |title=Russia ready to send request to US over questionings in Browder case |url=http://tass.com/world/1013707 |accessdate=19 July 2018 |work=TASS |date=17 July 2018 |language=ru}}) Well that‚Äôs their personal case. It might have been legal, the contribution itself but the way the money was earned was illegal. So we have solid reason to believe that some [US] intelligence officers accompanied and guided these transactions. So we have an interest in questioning them.
''[[PolitiFact|Politifact]]'', ''[[The Washington Post]]'' and ''[[The New York Times]]'' rated Putin's claim about the funding false, noting that there is no evidence to substantiate it.{{Cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/fact-checker/wp/2018/07/16/the-facts-missing-from-trump-and-putins-news-conference/|title=Analysis {{!}} The facts missing from Trump and Putin‚Äôs news conference|website=Washington Post|language=en|access-date=2018-07-18}}[http://www.politifact.com/truth-o-meter/statements/2018/jul/16/vladimir-putin/putins-pants-fire-claim-about-400-million-donation/ Vladimir Putin's pants on fire claim abouy $400 million donation] Politifact{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/07/16/world/europe/putin-bill-browder-magnitsky-investor.html|title=Who Is Bill Browder, Kremlin Foe Singled Out in Putin‚Äôs Offer?|access-date=2018-07-18|language=en}} Bill Browder, in his own article for ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'', called the accusation "so ludicrous and untrue that it falls into delusion." He maintains that Putin continues to accuse him of false allegations in response to Browder's involvement with the Magnitsky Act. Browder also points out that he is a British citizen and no longer American, therefore Trump would be unable to respond to Putin's request.{{Cite web|url=http://time.com/5340545/bill-browder-vladimir-putin-magnitsky-act-donald-trump/|title=I'm Bill Browder. Here's the Biggest Mistake Putin Made When Trying to Get Access to Me Through Trump|website=Time|language=en|access-date=2018-07-19}} ==See also== *[[Russia under Vladimir Putin]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons cat|Bill Browder}} * {{Official website|http://billbrowder.com/}} * [https://archive.is/20061221074614/http://www.gsb.stanford.edu/news/bmag/sbsm0611/feature_browder.html Profile of Browder], Stanford Business School alumni magazine *[http://www.opalesque.tv/youtube/William_Browder_Bill_Browder/ Video ‚Äì Bill Browder: Sergey Magnitsky case reveals Russia's ugliest face], ''Opalesque FIVE Minutes'', 02/17/2010 * [http://www.slideshare.net/simonau/tatler "The Browder Ultimatum"], ''Tatler'' magazine, June 2010 * [https://web.archive.org/web/20130120114901/http://www.charlierose.com/view/interview/12560 Video ‚Äì Interview with Browder], ''Charlie Rose Show'' * {{C-SPAN|William F Browder}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Browder, Bill}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:1964 births]] [[Category:American emigrants to England]] [[Category:American expatriates in Russia]] [[Category:American non-fiction writers]] [[Category:American people of Russian-Jewish descent]] [[Category:Boston Consulting Group people]] [[Category:Businesspeople from Chicago]] [[Category:Corruption in Russia]] [[Category:Gazprom people]] [[Category:Place of birth missing (living people)]] [[Category:Stanford Graduate School of Business alumni]] [[Category:University of Chicago alumni]] [[Category:University of Colorado alumni]] [[Category:English expatriates in Russia]] [[Category:Naturalised citizens of the United Kingdom]] [[Category:English businesspeople]] [[Category:English non-fiction writers]] [[Category:English people of Russian-Jewish descent]] [[Category:Browder family]] [[Category:Magnitsky Act]]
